body: Thanks for the report, @rmarx . Could you try #10015, if this fixes h1/h2 requests for you?
The fix makes the problem go away in my test.

I too can confirm #10015 fixes the issue I was seeing :) 
Thanks for the quick response!

Hi! BoringSSL maintainer here. Came across this. I don't think the workaround is right. I haven't tried it, but I believe the bug is actually these lines here:
https://github.com/curl/curl/blob/bd9c9a4ea145f12bb535f85034fbbf48674a2549/lib/vtls/openssl.c#L718
https://github.com/curl/curl/blob/bd9c9a4ea145f12bb535f85034fbbf48674a2549/lib/vtls/openssl.c#L748

`BIO_read` and `BIO_write` return negative numbers on error, including retryable ones. This seems to have been a regression from https://github.com/curl/curl/commit/55807e6c056f27846d70cec70ee6ac3f0e5b3bbe. Both branches should be returning -1.

The APIs are patterned after POSIX `read` and `write` which, similarly, return -1 on errors, not zero, with `EAGAIN` treated as an error:
https://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/009604599/functions/read.html

That (newer) OpenSSL isn't noticing it is due a mess of quirks around stemming from them mixing some things up when introducing the `BIO_read_ex` APIs. (See https://github.com/openssl/openssl/issues/8208; they basically forgot that `BIO_read` already had an EOF convention and thought -1 and 0 were the same.) I expect older OpenSSLs would have the same behavior as BoringSSL here. You can see how, in 1.0.2, `SSL_get_error` only returned `SSL_ERROR_WANT_READ` on -1, not 0:
https://github.com/openssl/openssl/blob/OpenSSL_1_0_2-stable/ssl/ssl_lib.c#L2729

Try, instead, reverting #10015, and then fixing 55807e6c056f27846d70cec70ee6ac3f0e5b3bbe to return -1 in those cases as well.

issue.title: openssl: return -1 on errors

repository.name: curl
repository.description: A command line tool and library for transferring data with URL syntax, supporting DICT, FILE, FTP, FTPS, GOPHER, GOPHERS, HTTP, HTTPS, IMAP, IMAPS, LDAP, LDAPS, MQTT, POP3, POP3S, RTMP, RTMPS, RTSP, SCP, SFTP, SMB, SMBS, SMTP, SMTPS, TELNET, TFTP, WS and WSS. libcurl offers a myriad of powerful features

issue.body:
BIO_read and BIO_write return negative numbers on error, including retryable ones. This seems to have been a regression from 55807e6. Both branches should be returning -1.

The APIs are patterned after POSIX read and write which, similarly, return -1 on errors, not zero, with EAGAIN treated as an error.

Reverts commit 5c27f6c452f02507b3bb9506e1079ea2f3943e4e and solves it differently.

Bug: https://github.com/curl/curl/issues/10013#issuecomment-1335308146
Reported-by: David Benjamin @davidben 

/cc @icing

body:
No problem! (Probably should confirm the alternate also avoids the issue. I read the code but could have missed something.) And apologies for the mess that is this API. I know these sorts of divergences can be frustrating. Do let us know if you run into problems like this! Even among the limited spaces BoringSSL is trying to target, it is useful to know about divergences and we may be able to help.

For our part, I have been eying how to add the read_ex and write_ex APIs without quite as bad of EOF problems, so I'll try to keep this fun case in mind when figuring the right way to do it. It's always a challenge getting the right balance of aligning with OpenSSL (and figuring out what that even means!), while also keeping the library consistent with itself, with past OpenSSL behavior, and standards. Ideally those two goals would be the same, but alas I've found they diverge more often than I'd like. :-(
PR #10021 at least runs all the tests fine now - and my few manual tests showed no problems.

@davidben I understand the pain regarding this API. And thanks for the support. Since there is another *SSL that also diverges on the BIO error handling, I think I stick with my approach of inspecting the result of the last IO operation stashed away and take the SSL return code as a hint.
